base_prompt: An engineer claims: "Enclaves can safely do arbitrary system calls directly." In the context of Intel SGX, correct this statement and explain the right trust boundary and TCB assumptions. Include one concrete example of a failure if the team believes the incorrect claim.

An engineer claims: "If code runs in the secure world, the TCB is automatically tiny." In the context of Arm TrustZone, correct this statement and explain the right trust boundary and TCB assumptions. Include one concrete example of a failure if the team believes the incorrect claim.

An engineer claims: "SEV-SNP means the guest is secure even if the CPU has speculative-execution bugs." In the context of AMD SEV-SNP, correct this statement and explain the right trust boundary and TCB assumptions. Include one concrete example of a failure if the team believes the incorrect claim.

An engineer claims: "SGX attestation proves the OS is trustworthy." In the context of Intel SGX, correct this statement and explain the right trust boundary and TCB assumptions. Include one concrete example of a failure if the team believes the incorrect claim.

An engineer claims: "TDX means the hypervisor cannot influence anything about the VM." In the context of Intel TDX, correct this statement and explain the right trust boundary and TCB assumptions. Include one concrete example of a failure if the team believes the incorrect claim.

An engineer claims: "TEE memory is always safe from side channels by design." In the context of Intel SGX, correct this statement and explain the right trust boundary and TCB assumptions. Include one concrete example of a failure if the team believes the incorrect claim.

An engineer claims: "TrustZone gives each app its own enclave, like SGX." In the context of Arm TrustZone, correct this statement and explain the right trust boundary and TCB assumptions. Include one concrete example of a failure if the team believes the incorrect claim.

Boundary precision check: In Arm TrustZone, what state is shared with the untrusted world (memory, caches, interrupts, scheduling) and what state is intended to be isolated? Answer assuming the normal-world OS is compromised.

Boundary precision check: In Arm TrustZone, what state is shared with the untrusted world (memory, caches, interrupts, scheduling) and what state is intended to be isolated? Answer assuming an attacker can run a malicious normal-world kernel module.

Boundary precision check: In GlobalPlatform TEE, what state is shared with the untrusted world (memory, caches, interrupts, scheduling) and what state is intended to be isolated? Answer assuming the normal-world OS is compromised.

Boundary precision check: In Intel SGX, what state is shared with the untrusted world (memory, caches, interrupts, scheduling) and what state is intended to be isolated? Answer assuming the OS and hypervisor are compromised.

Boundary precision check: In Intel SGX, what state is shared with the untrusted world (memory, caches, interrupts, scheduling) and what state is intended to be isolated? Answer assuming a co-tenant can run untrusted code on the same machine.

Boundary precision check: In OP-TEE (TrustZone TEE OS), what state is shared with the untrusted world (memory, caches, interrupts, scheduling) and what state is intended to be isolated? Answer assuming the normal-world OS is compromised.
Compare Arm TrustZone isolation with process/container isolation. Give two examples of what the TEE protects against and two examples it does not, under the normal-world OS is compromised.

Compare Arm TrustZone isolation with process/container isolation. Give two examples of what the TEE protects against and two examples it does not, under an attacker can run a malicious normal-world kernel module.
Compare GlobalPlatform TEE isolation with process/container isolation. Give two examples of what the TEE protects against and two examples it does not, under the normal-world OS is compromised.
Compare Intel SGX isolation with process/container isolation. Give two examples of what the TEE protects against and two examples it does not, under the OS and hypervisor are compromised.

Compare Intel SGX isolation with process/container isolation. Give two examples of what the TEE protects against and two examples it does not, under a co-tenant can run untrusted code on the same machine.

Compare OP-TEE (TrustZone TEE OS) isolation with process/container isolation. Give two examples of what the TEE protects against and two examples it does not, under the normal-world OS is compromised.

Describe how trusted I/O works (or fails) in Arm TrustZone: what can be trusted about keyboard/display/network/storage, and what additional mechanisms are needed if the normal-world OS is compromised?

Describe how trusted I/O works (or fails) in Arm TrustZone: what can be trusted about keyboard/display/network/storage, and what additional mechanisms are needed if an attacker can run a malicious normal-world kernel module?

Describe how trusted I/O works (or fails) in GlobalPlatform TEE: what can be trusted about keyboard/display/network/storage, and what additional mechanisms are needed if the normal-world OS is compromised?
Describe how trusted I/O works (or fails) in Intel SGX: what can be trusted about keyboard/display/network/storage, and what additional mechanisms are needed if the OS and hypervisor are compromised?

Describe how trusted I/O works (or fails) in Intel SGX: what can be trusted about keyboard/display/network/storage, and what additional mechanisms are needed if a co-tenant can run untrusted code on the same machine?

Describe how trusted I/O works (or fails) in OP-TEE (TrustZone TEE OS): what can be trusted about keyboard/display/network/storage, and what additional mechanisms are needed if the normal-world OS is compromised?

Explain the lifecycle of a enclave/VM from creation/initialization to teardown. Where can secrets leak during transitions (entry/exit, exceptions, I/O), and what are the usual mitigations at a high level?

Explain the lifecycle of a secure-world service from creation/initialization to teardown. Where can secrets leak during transitions (entry/exit, exceptions, I/O), and what are the usual mitigations at a high level?

In AMD SEV-SNP, discuss the challenges of keypad / touch input. What can the TEE realistically protect, what remains untrusted, and what additional system components (drivers, secure display, secure channel endpoints) are typically required under the assumption that the hypervisor is malicious?

In AMD SEV-SNP, discuss the challenges of trusted UI / display path. What can the TEE realistically protect, what remains untrusted, and what additional system components (drivers, secure display, secure channel endpoints) are typically required under the assumption that the hypervisor is malicious?

In Arm TrustZone, discuss the challenges of keypad / touch input. What can the TEE realistically protect, what remains untrusted, and what additional system components (drivers, secure display, secure channel endpoints) are typically required under the assumption that the normal-world OS is compromised?

In Arm TrustZone, discuss the challenges of trusted UI / display path. What can the TEE realistically protect, what remains untrusted, and what additional system components (drivers, secure display, secure channel endpoints) are typically required under the assumption that the normal-world OS is compromised?

In Intel SGX, discuss the challenges of keypad / touch input. What can the TEE realistically protect, what remains untrusted, and what additional system components (drivers, secure display, secure channel endpoints) are typically required under the assumption that the OS is compromised?

In Intel SGX, discuss the challenges of trusted UI / display path. What can the TEE realistically protect, what remains untrusted, and what additional system components (drivers, secure display, secure channel endpoints) are typically required under the assumption that the OS is compromised?

You're reviewing a design that uses Arm TrustZone. Explain the isolation boundary in one paragraph, then list the concrete components that belong to the TCB (hardware, firmware, privileged software). Assume the normal-world OS is compromised.

You're reviewing a design that uses Arm TrustZone. Explain the isolation boundary in one paragraph, then list the concrete components that belong to the TCB (hardware, firmware, privileged software). Assume an attacker can run a malicious normal-world kernel module.

You're reviewing a design that uses GlobalPlatform TEE. Explain the isolation boundary in one paragraph, then list the concrete components that belong to the TCB (hardware, firmware, privileged software). Assume the normal-world OS is compromised.

You're reviewing a design that uses Intel SGX. Explain the isolation boundary in one paragraph, then list the concrete components that belong to the TCB (hardware, firmware, privileged software). Assume the OS and hypervisor are compromised.

You're reviewing a design that uses Intel SGX. Explain the isolation boundary in one paragraph, then list the concrete components that belong to the TCB (hardware, firmware, privileged software). Assume a co-tenant can run untrusted code on the same machine.

You're reviewing a design that uses OP-TEE (TrustZone TEE OS). Explain the isolation boundary in one paragraph, then list the concrete components that belong to the TCB (hardware, firmware, privileged software). Assume the normal-world OS is compromised.
Attestation and time: why is 'freshness' hard without a trusted clock? Discuss high-level approaches (nonces, short-lived tokens, server-side state) and their tradeoffs.
Attestation-based key exchange: outline how to bind an ephemeral key to an attested identity without trusting the network. Keep it high level (no code).

Design question: a service wants to provision a long-term key only to a enclave/VM after successful SGX remote attestation. Describe a secure provisioning flow at a high level and list the assumptions that must hold. Include how to handle revocation/updates under a malicious OS/hypervisor.

Design question: a service wants to provision a long-term key only to a enclave/VM after successful SGX DCAP attestation. Describe a secure provisioning flow at a high level and list the assumptions that must hold. Include how to handle revocation/updates under a cloud environment with changing TCB levels.

Design question: a service wants to provision a long-term key only to a TEE application after successful TrustZone/TEE attestation. Describe a secure provisioning flow at a high level and list the assumptions that must hold. Include how to handle revocation/updates under a mobile device fleet with OEM variations.

Design question: a service wants to provision a long-term key only to a enclave/VM after successful SEV-SNP attestation. Describe a secure provisioning flow at a high level and list the assumptions that must hold. Include how to handle revocation/updates under a malicious hypervisor.

Design question: a service wants to provision a long-term key only to a enclave/VM after successful TDX attestation. Describe a secure provisioning flow at a high level and list the assumptions that must hold. Include how to handle revocation/updates under a malicious hypervisor.
Explain the difference between attesting *code identity* and attesting *runtime state*. Why is runtime state hard to attest robustly?
Explain why 'attestation proves confidentiality' is an overclaim. Provide a correct, scoped statement a team can put in a security report.

Explain why attestation does not (by itself) guarantee absence of malicious *configuration* or insecure deployment settings. Give examples of deployment-level risks that survive even when code identity is correct.

Given a verifier that receives an attestation artifact, outline the verification steps (identity, freshness, TCB status) at a high level. What can go wrong if the verifier skips freshness (nonce/challenge) checks?

Given a verifier that receives an attestation artifact, outline the verification steps (identity, freshness, TCB status) at a high level. What can go wrong if the verifier trusts a self-signed attestation blob?

Given a verifier that receives an attestation artifact, outline the verification steps (identity, freshness, TCB status) at a high level. What can go wrong if the verifier does not validate TCB status or revocation?

Given a verifier that receives an attestation artifact, outline the verification steps (identity, freshness, TCB status) at a high level. What can go wrong if the verifier binds secrets to an identity but ignores versioning policies?

Given a verifier that receives an attestation artifact, outline the verification steps (identity, freshness, TCB status) at a high level. What can go wrong if the system assumes attestation implies resistance to side channels?

Given a verifier that receives an attestation artifact, outline the verification steps (identity, freshness, TCB status) at a high level. What can go wrong if the system accepts attestation without pinning the expected enclave/TA measurement?

Given a verifier that receives an attestation artifact, outline the verification steps (identity, freshness, TCB status) at a high level. What can go wrong if the verifier does not check the signing chain / root of trust correctly?
How should an attestation verifier handle platform TCB updates and revocation without bricking legitimate clients? Provide a high-level strategy.

In the context of SEV-SNP attestation, explain the role of a nonce/challenge in preventing replay. What is the minimum verifier state needed to ensure freshness, and what failures occur if an adversary can record and replay old attestation tokens under a malicious hypervisor?

In the context of SGX DCAP attestation, explain the role of a nonce/challenge in preventing replay. What is the minimum verifier state needed to ensure freshness, and what failures occur if an adversary can record and replay old attestation tokens under a cloud environment with changing TCB levels?

In the context of SGX remote attestation, explain the role of a nonce/challenge in preventing replay. What is the minimum verifier state needed to ensure freshness, and what failures occur if an adversary can record and replay old attestation tokens under a malicious OS/hypervisor?

In the context of TDX attestation, explain the role of a nonce/challenge in preventing replay. What is the minimum verifier state needed to ensure freshness, and what failures occur if an adversary can record and replay old attestation tokens under a malicious hypervisor?

In the context of TrustZone/TEE attestation, explain the role of a nonce/challenge in preventing replay. What is the minimum verifier state needed to ensure freshness, and what failures occur if an adversary can record and replay old attestation tokens under a mobile device fleet with OEM variations?
Multi-tenant setting: what privacy or linkability concerns can arise when using attestation tokens across sessions, and what mitigations exist?

Policy question: when is it acceptable to use SGX DCAP attestation as an access-control gate? Provide a nuanced answer considering that the platform’s TCB is updated frequently (microcode/firmware churn) and a cloud environment with changing TCB levels.

Policy question: when is it acceptable to use SGX remote attestation as an access-control gate? Provide a nuanced answer considering that the attacker can run co-tenant workloads and measure timing/cache effects and a malicious OS/hypervisor.

Policy question: when is it acceptable to use TDX attestation as an access-control gate? Provide a nuanced answer considering that the attacker can reboot the device and attempt rollback and a malicious hypervisor.

Policy question: when is it acceptable to use TDX attestation as an access-control gate? Provide a nuanced answer considering that the provisioning server could be targeted by supply-chain attacks and a malicious hypervisor.

Policy question: when is it acceptable to use TrustZone/TEE attestation as an access-control gate? Provide a nuanced answer considering that side channels are explicitly in scope and a mobile device fleet with OEM variations.

Remote verifier question: explain how to bind an authorization decision to a specific enclave/TA measurement while still supporting emergency patching. What policies should the verifier encode (e.g., allowlisted signer + minimum version), and why?

Sealed storage question: explain what sealing binds data to in the context of SGX remote attestation, and how rollback and migration should be handled when updating the enclave/VM. Include a note on versioning and anti-rollback assumptions.

Sealed storage question: explain what sealing binds data to in the context of SGX DCAP attestation, and how rollback and migration should be handled when updating the enclave/VM. Include a note on versioning and anti-rollback assumptions.

Sealed storage question: explain what sealing binds data to in the context of TrustZone/TEE attestation, and how rollback and migration should be handled when updating the TEE application. Include a note on versioning and anti-rollback assumptions.

Sealed storage question: explain what sealing binds data to in the context of SEV-SNP attestation, and how rollback and migration should be handled when updating the enclave/VM. Include a note on versioning and anti-rollback assumptions.

Sealed storage question: explain what sealing binds data to in the context of TDX attestation, and how rollback and migration should be handled when updating the enclave/VM. Include a note on versioning and anti-rollback assumptions.

A team says: "A TEE eliminates the need to patch speculative-execution vulnerabilities." Under threat model "remote attacker plus co-tenant timing attacks", is that claim valid? If not, rewrite it into a correct, scoped statement.

A team says: "Attestation guarantees the software stack is secure end-to-end." Under threat model "OS compromised; attacker has root in normal world", is that claim valid? If not, rewrite it into a correct, scoped statement.

A team says: "If keys are sealed, rollback is impossible." Under threat model "remote attacker plus co-tenant timing attacks", is that claim valid? If not, rewrite it into a correct, scoped statement.

A team says: "Trusted execution implies trusted input/output by default." Under threat model "OS compromised; attacker has root in normal world", is that claim valid? If not, rewrite it into a correct, scoped statement.

A team says: "Using a TEE means we can trust the entire platform outside the enclave/secure world." Under threat model "OS compromised; attacker has root in normal world", is that claim valid? If not, rewrite it into a correct, scoped statement.

Build a simple threat model table (assets, adversaries, entry points, mitigations) for a payment service stores API keys and uses SGX enclaves for key handling. Keep it TEE-specific and explicit about what is and is not in the TCB.

Build a simple threat model table (assets, adversaries, entry points, mitigations) for a mobile banking app uses TrustZone to store biometric templates and signing keys. Keep it TEE-specific and explicit about what is and is not in the TCB.

Build a simple threat model table (assets, adversaries, entry points, mitigations) for a confidential ML inference service runs in a VM protected by SEV-SNP. Keep it TEE-specific and explicit about what is and is not in the TCB.

Build a simple threat model table (assets, adversaries, entry points, mitigations) for a multi-tenant SaaS uses TDX VMs to isolate customer workloads from the hypervisor. Keep it TEE-specific and explicit about what is and is not in the TCB.

Compare Intel TDX vs AMD SEV-SNP under the threat model: malicious hypervisor; physical access not assumed. What changes in the TCB and what risks remain?

Compare Intel TDX vs Intel SGX under the threat model: malicious hypervisor; physical access not assumed. What changes in the TCB and what risks remain?
Compare Intel TDX vs Intel SGX under the threat model: physical attacker with device access and glitching equipment. What changes in the TCB and what risks remain?

Threat-model this system: a DRM system uses a TEE to decrypt media keys on-device. List attacker capabilities, in-scope/out-of-scope threats, and the resulting trust boundary. Then state whether a TEE helps and why.

Contrast two attacks: DMA attacks and IOMMU limits vs branch predictor mistraining risks. How do they differ in mechanism and what does that imply for TEE security assumptions?
Contrast two attacks: Foreshadow/L1TF-style leakage against enclaves vs Rowhammer-like memory disturbance. How do they differ in mechanism and what does that imply for TEE security assumptions?
Contrast two attacks: LVI (Load Value Injection) vs Spectre-style speculative execution. How do they differ in mechanism and what does that imply for TEE security assumptions?
Contrast two attacks: MDS / ZombieLoad class leakage vs Rowhammer-like memory disturbance. How do they differ in mechanism and what does that imply for TEE security assumptions?
